comment.body: There's the [ZeroNet Dev Center](/14pM9huTYzJdyQyHRj6v2kfhMe8DrxwpGt/?/) that has a couple of tutorials on it (You might want to start with [this one](/14pM9huTYzJdyQyHRj6v2kfhMe8DrxwpGt/?/tutorials/the_basics)). I try to make the tutorials as in-depth as possible. I'm working on writing more. It also provides [a place](/14pM9huTYzJdyQyHRj6v2kfhMe8DrxwpGt/?/questions) to ask questions and get answers related to ZeroNet Development (like stack-overflow, but not as feature-rich).

imo, ZeroNet isn't dead. However, sometimes there isn't that much conversation on ZeroMe, and sometimes there's much more than now. It all depends on the time I guess. It also helps if you get all of the hubs from the [Get All Hubs Zite](/0hub.bit).

@Stolivodka: ZeroNet is definitely farther than "hello world" imo. Right now it's actually functional and usable - we already have many pretty good zites: ZeroMe, ZeroMail, ZeroTalk, ZeroVoat, ZeroSites, Kopy Kate, Thunderwave, ZeroBlog, ZeroNet Dev Center (the questions part), ZeroWiki, 0Play, ZeroTV (not being updated anymore afaik), Git Over ZeroNet, Search Engines like Kaffie, Zirch, and RVRE, IFS, something that I'm currently working on that will be released hopefully soon. Sure these may not be as good as the clearnet alternatives, but that's what you get when you are dealing with only a subset of the clearnet (no php/nodejs, no instant updates because there's not a central server so everything needs to be signed and published, etc.) IMO, ZeroNet has done some things that are kinda cool and would at the very least qualify it as a beta (considering how easy it is to setup, although could probably still be improved, how friendly it is to navigate, and all the different zites we have) - MergerZites, Optional Files, [Big File Support](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/7) *coming soon* (I believe this includes *streaming* content), Cloning, the way it handles Users, etc.
I give some information on how ZeroNet and its Zites work on the first tutorial on my [ZeroNet Dev Center](http://127.0.0.1:43110/14pM9huTYzJdyQyHRj6v2kfhMe8DrxwpGt/?/tutorials/the_basics) zite.

You could have also translated the zeroframe javascript file into Dart code, that's what I did with typescript. However, I don't know how hard that would be with Dart, I don't know much about that language.

I use ZeroMe to keep people up to date on my ZeroNet development progress. I think I'm one of the ones who uses it quite a bit more than others. I only post about development stuff because I don't have much else to post about.
You can make the full multiplication table using nested for loops. What's the point of `result`?

@Shouko: Are you sure it's not *intended to* replace both @zeroid.bit and @zeroverse.bit with an empty string? Otherwise it wouldn't make sense to replace zeroid.bit with zeroverse.bit However, I don't know if you can pass in *3* strings into the replace function (which is why I said *intended*).

Thanks! I'm currently working on a big update! One of the things is Image Support (via Optional Files). I'm also working on making the zite feel a bit smoother by adding some caching so pages that don't change much (like the homepage, the stories page, and your profile page) don't have to reload every time you go to them.

@Collect: What do you mean? You need to be way more specific if I'm gonna be able to fix these problems! Do you mean the Sign In button doesn't work? This next update will hopefully fix some of these weird problems. The update will probably be done tomorrow.

@Collect: And just because something doesn't work, doesn't mean it's not *supposed* to work. How would other people be able to post when signing in doesn't work at least some of the time *or* previously. Meaning, there is authorization (in the sense of signin in) but it seems you assumed not because the sign in wasn't working. However, assuming isn't so good considering the signin is supposed to work and either has worked or is working for some people. So instead of making assumptions, **maybe you can try giving me details of what isn't working and what exactly you did that led up to it not working.**

@Collect: Sorry if I seem snippy or rude, but people have told me before that things don't work, but then don't give *any* details of what *exactly* isn't working and what led up to it not working. It just kinda gets frustrating.
@Collect: Okay, can you give step by step instructions on what exactly you did when you went to register, including the button names you pressed - *everything*.

@Collect: One thing that might get confusing for people is which button to click. If you already have an id from an id provider (like zeroid, kaffieid, etc.), then you should be clicking `Sign In` rather than one of the registering buttons. I have renamed these buttons and added better instructions in the next update so people don't get confused.

@Collect: Okay, follow these instructions.
Click/touch and drag the circle with a 0 in the center (in the top right corner) to the right. Scroll down till you see `Identity Address`. Click `Change`, then click `Unique to Site`. Then refresh the page and try again.

@Collect: If it was the button names that were confusing, sorry about that! I changed the names of them instantly after I realized that they could be confusing. However, these changes won't appear until the next update.
How would I upload an *existing* git repo? I would like to transfer my repos from GitHub to this.

A few more things:
* Does the author email have to be the same as git's email?
* It keeps on asking to add a new site, even though I already did, everytime I click on a tab
* Publishing to the Repo Index isn't working. Here's the error message when clicking on the "Publish to Repository Index" button:
```
Internal error: Exception: Merger site (GitCenter) does not have permission for merged site: 1iNDExENNBsfHc6SKmy1HaeasHhm3RPcL (None
```

Okay, so I fixed the problem with the publishing to repository index by going to the repo index merger site [here](/1iNDExENNBsfHc6SKmy1HaeasHhm3RPcL). Then, it downloads it and redirects to Git Center. After that I am able to successfully publish to the repo index. After I did this, I no longer get that problem with it asking to add a site whenever I goto a new page/tab.

I'm actually starting another class so I won't be online again. Yeah, I was thinking that the merger zites weren't being downloaded before they were trying to be merged/added.

This would also require updating all repo merger zites - there is an `update code` button for cloned zites, but I don't know if that would erase/reset the git repo.

@Git Center: Oh. I didn't think about that - and didn't notice that sign argument before. However, if you are using the command from GitCenter, then it could be publishing GitCenter and not the merger zite because I don't see an argument to give it the zite to publish.

I don't know, sometimes ZeroNet is weird.

@Git Center: You could try using the sign command, then publish - separate the two, that way if there are no peers, it will still sign. That is, if what I said below is the way it behaves.

So, I just looked up that issue, and found the person who posted it - Imachug/Ivanq. Basically, I keep up to date with ZeroNet issues.

@Git Center: Ok. Thanks for all your work!

@Git Center: So, releases are based on tags. A release points to a tag and a branch. When you create a release, it has you create a new tag and pick the branch (or a commit) - then it will set the tag to the head of the branch you picked (or to the commit if you picked a commit). Then you can create a description for the release. It automatically puts a zip file in there that allows you to download the repo at that tag/release, but you can also upload additional files - which is useful for distribution files (executables, packages as in deb, rpm, etc).
@Git Center: What do you mean by Mirror feature. Do you mean the ability to show github repo information on gitcenter, kinda like the ZeroNet Dev News Bot on ZeroTalk, but with more information?

@Git Center: I don't think so because git doesn't have something like a release. Releases are a Github thing. However, you can make a tag via the command line, but there's no notion of description, etc as far as I know. So, what you could do is, when creating a release, just have the user pick a tag that they would have had to create via the command line.

@Git Center: Well, you can set a tag to a commit or branch though. That is what I was meaning by having them create the tag manually, then just letting them pick a tag when creating a release - that way your zite doesn't have to create the tag.
Also, there is a way to created annotated tags in git. I don't know if you can use that as a description. Here's the syntax for this:
```
git tag -a v1.4 -m 'my version 1.4'
```
@Git Center: Yeah, that could work.
@Git Center: Really, GitHub releases are just tags with additional information associated with them, like description and files.
@Git Center: Also, you might want to warn people about the blue button not working for the first time, and how they can initially sign their repo.
@Git Center: I was thinking maybe the content.json file doesn't get signed after adding the user's auth_address to the "signers" field. I don't know. I don't understand it either.

@Git Center: However, maybe it's because using an id to sign with doesn't work until you have at least 1 other peer. Because otherwise you could just add your id to the "signers" field and sign the file without having permission then everyone would allow it. But by restricting it to only do it after at least 1 peer, the peers would be able to check from the previous content.json file that the signer is allowed. I don't know if this is how it works. Does this make sense?
@Git Center: If it does work like that, maybe you can check for peer count, and if there are no peers, then use the private key. Otherwise, use the user's id to sign with.
@Git Center: Yep, I'll check! :)
@Git Center: Okay, so I am getting my unannotated tag listed in there.
@Krixano: Hold on. I'm not sure if it is unnanotated or not actually, since it was created by github.

@Git Center: Two issues so far. I think all tags, regardless of if they are annotated or not are shown in the releases tab (not sure if this is actually how you want it though). And, the log tab isn't loading the commits anymore.
@Git Center: Also, the log page doesn't have all of the tabs listed at the top.

@Git Center: Well, I was originally thinking that after the user created the tag, they then click a button on the zite to create a release and give it the tag name. That way they can tell the zite which tags are releases and which aren't. Also, I recommend muting qubesi2p@zeroid.bit
@Git Center: Yeah, a button like that would be fine. However, if you want every tag to be considered a release, then you probably don't need to bother with that.
@Git Center: That could work too. That might be better if you anticipate people using tags more for releases than not.
@Git Center: I have another thing (btw, tell me if I'm pestering you with too many things to do). Add the ability to see what was changed in a commit.
@Git Center: Yeah.
@Git Center: The signing problem is the other thing. That's all I can think of for now.
@Git Center: Oh, one more! Line numbers when showing the contents of a file.
@Git Center: Yeah, that might be good to add too. Thanks for all your work - you created a pretty great zite!
@Git Center: Good Night!

Kaffiene hasn't been updated in forever as far as I know (it doesn't even have *any* of my zites, 2 of which have been out for many months now), which is why I reccommend [Zirch](/1SearchPd3khzLtsxTxKYhYUohk7c1QYd/) (which is almost at 4000 sites). It has the biggest number of zites and is updated every hour. In fact your zite is already on there.
@Krixano: Another thing, blocking people from creating issues and pull requests.

@Nofish: There's problems with signing and publishing initially, until you gets peers I believe (we did some testing on this with my repos). However, my repos should work (I manually signed them from the merger zite, all information on this in the *long* conversation below), ZeroMedium, ZeroDB, and Krixano's Zite. They work on my phone and on bigcat.tk (which I'm not using anymore).

@Sksn: Oh, you mean a system where nobody knows who said what. That's not a very good idea in my opinion. Nobody would be able to know anyone so you don't know who your talking to and you can't find out. You also wouldn't be able to donate to anyone, mention anyone (for example, what if I wanted to report a bug to Nofish, but I can't mention him, so he may never know about the report).
I also don't get why it's needed. You're already anonymous in the sense that no one will know what your real name is, where your located unless you tell people.

@Sksn: The only consequence I see is connecting your stuff here to stuff you said on the clearnet, where they can then identify you. But that's kinda on you isn't it? They can also still do this without pseudonyms.
@Git Center: Yeah. I think adding it to settings tab will not only making it a bit easier, but also help people who don't know how to mute people in the user's content.json file.

@Git Center: I only recommend zirch because it's the *only* one that is constantly updated and therefore has the most zites (that is until EulerFinder was released, but I don't know which one has more zites, etc.). RVRE hasn't been updated in a while. Same with Kaffie and Snifferdog. If RVRE was updated, I would actually use that over Zirch.
@Git Center: Yeah, but I told him he needed to resign his repository, but as far as I know, he hasn't yet.
@Git Center: I wouldn't find it useful because I don't really go on twitter. However, other people might.

@Git Center: If I had a dedicated computer I could use to crawl zites (like what Zirch does), then I would create my own search engine that looks as good as RVRE, but is constantly updated like Zirch. I'd also improve the descriptions, because I do agree that that part of zirch needs to be improved. I also think the searching mechanism can be improved a little too.

@Git Center: One of the things I wish was improved with ZeroNet is the content. I'm in agreement with @Styromaniac: that we need more original content on here, especially stuff that's not programming related. This is the main reason why I created ZeroMedium.

@Git Center: Yeah, that's the main problem. I guess this stems from the fact that a lot of people on here are techy people and that we don't have that many people on here. And that could stem from other people not knowing the benefit of this project, *or* perhaps because they don't know how to set ZeroNet up, *or* maybe even because the only people who find out about ZeroNet are techy people. So, *I think we need to increase the discoverability of ZeroNet and better explain the benefits of it (or increase the benefits of it to fit more in line with what people put more importance on).*

@Git Center: I think that's mostly because a lot of the people on here aren't content creators. Heck, people *barely* post stuff on ZeroMe most of the time. It could also just be that there isn't enough people and enough variety of people.

@Git Center: No, and it's hard to tell because people have multiple accounts. Also, going by peer count isn't reliable either because not only do people have multiple devices, but a device cannot always connect to every other peer of a zite.

@Git Center: Another thing to keep in mind is that a lot of accounts might have been used just a little, and then the people just stopped using either ZeroMe or ZeroNet. I'd say there's probably more than 50 users, but that 50 is probably more of how many users are *active* (or at least it seems this way).

@Git Center: Actually, I was just going to say we could switch over to this: [ThunderWave](/thunderwave.bit) created by @Glightstar: . It's a public chat. Also I'm surprised I am even allowed to post on SunHub, because my content was full. Nofish must have increased my limit.
@Git Center: Yeah, that's fine with me.
ZeroTube never works. You should use Kopy Kate Big instead: [/18Pfr2oswXvD352BbJvo59gZ3GbdbipSzh/](/18Pfr2oswXvD352BbJvo59gZ3GbdbipSzh/)

You have to have *every* field filled out.
@Infected: Sorry, I don't know then, since it works for me.

@Zeptobyte: What you could do is have a server that runs, every hour or day, through all the torrents and gets the seeder amount and save that in the zite's database. That way the visitor doesn't have to connect to all torrents while searching. The only thing is the seeder amount could still be a little wrong (since you probably wouldn't want to run this constantly). But it would update eventually (depending on how often you check for seeders).
Is there good support for VueJs with Dart?
@Zeptobyte: Well, all it really requires is a computer that's constantly running. It doesn't have to actually be a server (in the sense of having server software and/or hardware).
Showing the username/cert_user_id on repo might be useful.
@Git Center: Yeah.
@Git Center: Looks good. Thanks!
@Git Center: Yeah, that'd also be good.

@Binchan: Searching with a space only gets me 9 torrents. I wonder why this is the case only for me. I even tried clearing the cache.

I don't even understand why people are doing this in the first place, it doesn't do anything but add an annoying thing where we have to click yet another thing to get to where we need to go. You can use [ZeroMedium](/ZeroMedium.bit) for blogging/essay/story/tutorial-type stuff, especially when you're writing a lot. It supports inline markdown, images, multiple languages (partially, interface is English-only right now, but topics and tags support other languages and you can set language of a story you post), uses an editor very similar to Medium, and in the next version will support Videos and Audio (will be released on December 15th).
What do you mean by Formatting? ZeroMe supports markdown, and therefore **bold**, *italics*, [links](/Me.ZeroNetwork.bit), bulleted lists, and headings.
I don't see the checkboxes. Did you publish the changes?
@Git Center: It's working now. Thanks!
I think it's a problem with your browser. Someone else has this problem too, but I can't quite remember the whole situation.
Are you Kopyjane?

@Missesrobot: Just be careful, or you'll be like me and have too many zites for you to manage (I have 5 zites so far, and I've neglected many of them for ZeroMedium - and I am currently making another, ZeroExchange).
btw, I think that KopyKate could be good with merger zites, but you have to do it correctly - which basically means *not* like ZeroMe.

@Missesrobot: There could be a few ways to organize them. You can create merger zites for each category of video, and you could let the person choose the category for the video and that video will be posted to the merger zite corresponding to that category. However, this would mean that every video has to have one main category and can't go into multiple categories (unless you want to duplicate the video).

@Missesrobot: You could also create merger zites for each profile. This might actually be a very good way to do it. And downloading a person's profile (merger zite) would be like subscribing/following them. You'll also need an index merger zite so that you can at least put all video titles/info into that so people don't have to have the profiles downloaded in order to see all videos.

@Missesrobot: Yes it does. That's a downside if, for example, you want to just watch one of their videos to see what they are about. But in that case, you could potentially make a button to easily delete the zite. And it would also take time for the merger zite to download completely, so that may be an annoyance too.
@Missesrobot: Yeah, that's why I said you have to be careful with how you do merger zites.

I would just use vuejs. imo, much better/easier than maquette because it can handle bigger things more easily and simply. It's much simpler because your templates are actual html code, not render functions. There's also components, as well as Single File Components.

I don't know if using jquery over maquette will have that great of a performance benefit (if any at all). The readability is exactly why I like VueJs over maquette. Btw, good luck with trying to update content dynamically with jQuery :) For me, I'd never do it that way because everything gets disorganized, hard to read, you have to do a lot of things manually, you have to mess with id's or classes all of the time. But If it works well for you, then that all that's matters.

btw, jquery can pretty much be completely replaced with regular javascript, especially when just getting elements from the DOM (replacements include getElementByid, querySelector, querySelectorAll, and more I'm sure). [http://youmightnotneedjquery.com/](http://youmightnotneedjquery.com/)

I made a router library that helps quite a bit with this. I've used it on all of my zites (except Important Zites, because I haven't developed that for a long time). Here's the [GitHub link](https://github.com/krixano/ZeroFrame-Router).

@Missesrobot: You can delete the `module.exports`. That's for if you're using npm, gulp/webpack, and browserify. Yes, the back and forward stuff doesn't work very well, I've been thinking about how to fix that.
